displayName.text: Vivian and Seymour Milstein Family Heart Center

formattedAddress: 173 Fort Washington Ave, New York, NY 10032, USA
adrFormatAddress: 173 Fort Washington Ave, New York, NY 10032, USA

originalText.text: The entire staff did an exceptional job taking care of my brother. His last stop in ICU was the most special, as the attending Docter was the epitome of professionalism and humanity up to the end. They managed my brother’s last minutes with no pain, just peace and grace

text.text: The entire staff did an exceptional job taking care of my brother. His last stop in ICU was the most special, as the attending Docter was the epitome of professionalism and humanity up to the end. They managed my brother’s last minutes with no pain, just peace and grace

originalText.text: I received world class surgical care however subsequent care was less than stellar. Nurses and staff were personally caring however the over all four days of hospital stay were a nightmare that set my physical and mental state back substantially. Details just too numerous to list.

text.text: I received world class surgical care however subsequent care was less than stellar. Nurses and staff were personally caring however the over all four days of hospital stay were a nightmare that set my physical and mental state back substantially. Details just too numerous to list.

originalText.text:
took escalator at your center to 2nd fl and found a body wrapped in white sheets on a sofa of an empty waiting area, BLACK shoes where resting on the floor under the body.

my 730 am surgery was completed in good time. though I am still wondering why before the surgery a man (said his field was electrocardiology) wanted to know about my alcohol and cannabis consumption and why I had my insert on the right side of my chest.  He, a ROBERTO was not helpful and also made a crack that the history I gave about the left side of my torso brought him to the conclusion the 'it had been beaten up'.  What was his intention?

Another odd character was a teenager , about 5' 1" in a black and white horizontally striped dress which was an approximate 24" long.  She popped in to 'my presurgery curtained bed area' , with a discombobilated facial expression, appearing to desire to say something.  Minutes later I asked a woman who was one of the surgeons who operated on me about the young girl.  The surgeon responded by saying she 'would look into who the aforementioned person was'.  Moments later I was told by another person (I believe one of the nurses) "bless you".  Soon after these events I was wheeled in for surgery.  I would say the preamble was rather unreassuring and highly incompetent.

The 4 events I have cited seem rather unprofessional and I would prefer they were NOT BE INCLUDED  during my stay for  MY DEFIBRILLATION REPLACEMENT ON THE RIGHT SIDE OF MY CHEST.

i WOULD PRESUME ANYONE IN THEIR RIGHT MIND WOULD CONCUR WITH ME!

originalText.text: When is it okay not to notify the wife or any family who sits waiting for hours to hear from the performing doctor, who assured you several times , he will notify you after performing the procedure. Neither the nursing staff in the ICU or recovery called my phone which is in the records as the contact person. Sitting and waiting for a family member for more than six hours without even given a contact number in the hospital just in case something like this happens. It's totally unheard of the staff at such a prestigious hospital being irresponsible not notifying any family member when the patient left the operating room. Between the surgical staff and anesthesic staff didn't think it was necessary to inform the wife. Surely their was enough staff in the operating room to do this. Why did it come that this happened. There are protocols in placed. How did this happen?

originalText.text:
One would think that this is a COLUMBIA university hospital the service / system would be fantastic.  Well, It's NOT.

If you did your blood work, EKG, or X-Rays at the testing center make sure you follow up.  Otherwise, they lose your test.  You can call the hospital to find the record but the hospital will transfer you about 5 times and at the end, they will hang up.   It is plainly the most frustrating experience ever.

This isn't only the problem with the Heart Center.  I found that this is a general problem with Columbia Hospital.   The actual doctors may be qualified and great but the supporting staffs are just so very aweful.  Terrible terrible.
